metadata.title: Promotion effect of lanthanum on the Co/La/Ba ammonia synthesis catalysts—the influence of lanthanum content

IMAGE-HIGH-RES APCATA 15751 S0926-860X(16)30036-9 10.1016/j.apcata.2016.01.036 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 XRPD patterns of the cobalt-lanthanum catalyst precursors (in the oxide form). Fig. 2 (a) Pore size distribution curves of the cobalt-lanthanum catalyst precursors, (b) a sample N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm of the Co/La(7.4) catalyst precursor. Fig. 3 Temperature-programmed reduction of oxide systems containing cobalt and lanthanum; (a) mass loss (TG) curves, (b) MS signals of water (m/e=18); reduction conditions: sample mass approx. 15mg, gas flow 100mlmin-1, 10%H2/Ar. Fig. 4 XRPD patterns of the spent catalysts (in the reduced form). Fig. 5 SEM images of the post-reaction catalysts: Co/Ba, Co/La(1.8)/Ba, Co/La(19.3)/Ba, Co/La(55.7)/Ba after exposure to air (magnification: 50k, scal bar: 1μm). Fig. 6 EDX maps of a distribution of Co, La and Ba on the surface of the post-reaction catalysts: Co/La(1.8)/Ba, Co/La(19.3)/Ba and Co/La(55.7)/Ba after exposure to air. Fig. 7 Surface area of the active phase (SH2 values) of the cobalt-lanthanum catalysts estimated on the basis of chemisorption data. Fig. 8 Temperature-programmed desorption profiles for the selected cobalt-lanthanum catalysts. Table 1 Chemical composition of prepared catalysts. Catalyst symbol Co content a (wt.%) La content b (wt.%) Ba content c (mmolgCo −1) Co/Ba 73.4 0.0 1.5 Co/La(1.8)/Ba 71.5 1.8 1.6 Co/La(4.6)/Ba 62.8 4.6 1.6 Co/La(7.4)/Ba 59.3 7.4 1.4 Co/La(19.3)/Ba 50.8 19.3 1.4 Co/La(29.3)/Ba 40.5 29.3 1.3 Co/La(38.8)/Ba 38.5 38.8 1.3 Co/La(55.7)/Ba 28.3 55.7 1.3 a Determined by using thermogravimetric techniques [33]. b Determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES). c Estimated based on the mass balance before and after impregnation. Table 2 Textural characteristic of cobalt-lanthanum catalyst precursors. Precursor symbol SBET a (m2 g−1) VP b (cm3 g−1) Co3O4 42.9 0.298 Co/La(1.8) 71.4 0.422 Co/La(4.6) 70.7 0.401 Co/La(7.4) 86.5 0.432 Co/La(19.3) 62.9 0.359 Co/La(29.3) 51.7 0.309 Co/La(38.8) 48.6 0.266 Co/La(55.7) 24.5 0.128 a Specific BET surface area estimated on the basis of Brunauer–Emmett–Teller isotherm. b Total pore volume estimated on the basis of Barret–Joyner–Halenda isotherm. Table 3 Activity of the promoted cobalt catalysts in NH3 synthesis reaction expressed in terms of a productivity and TOF (measurement conditions: 400°C, 6.3MPa, gas (H2/N2 =3:1) flow rate=70dm3 h−1; overheating conditions: 600°C, 0.1MPa, gas (H2/N2 =3:1) flow rate=30dm3 h−1). Promotion effect of lanthanum on the Co/La/Ba ammonia synthesis catalysts—the influence of lanthanum content Magdalena Zybert a Aleksandra Tarka a Bogusław Mierzwa b Leszek Kępiński c Wioletta Raróg-Pilecka a ⁎ a Warsaw University of Technology, Faculty of Chemistry, Noakowskiego 3, 00-664 Warsaw, Poland Warsaw University of Technology Faculty of Chemistry Noakowskiego 3 Warsaw 00-664 Poland b Institute of Physical Chemistry of the Polish Academy of Sciences, Kasprzaka 44/52, 01-224 Warsaw, Poland Institute of Physical Chemistry of the Polish Academy of Sciences Kasprzaka 44/52 Warsaw 01-224 Poland c Institute of Low Temperature and Structure Research of the Polish Academy of Sciences, Okólna 2, 50-950 Wrocław, Poland Institute of Low Temperature and Structure Research of the Polish Academy of Sciences Okólna 2 Wrocław 50-950 Poland ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The effect of lanthanum content on catalytic properties of cobalt catalysts for ammonia synthesis has been studied. The amount of La in the studied catalysts ranged from 0 to 55.7wt.%, whereas the barium content was constant (approx. 1.5mmolgCo −1). The characterization studies included a determination of properties of the catalysts precursors (N2 physisorption, XRPD), as well as the catalysts in the active form (TPR-MS, XRPD, SEM-EDX and H2 chemisorption). The activity of the obtained Co/La/Ba catalysts in NH3 synthesis was tested in a flow differential reactor operating under conditions close to the industrial ones (p=6.3MPa, T=400°C, H2/N2 =3:1). It has been found that lanthanum plays the role of an effective structural promoter. However, there is a strong correlation between the La content in the catalysts and their properties: increasing amount of lanthanum is accompanied by the improvement in textural properties of both the precursors and catalysts in the reduced form. Lanthanum does not work as an activator for the cobalt surface. The increase in the activity of Co/La/Ba catalysts was observed as a result of a development of the active phase surface by increasing the La content. Keywords Ammonia synthesis Cobalt catalyst Promoter Lanthanum content 1 Introduction Nitrogen is necessary for the proper functioning of plant and animal cells. The form in which it is present in air, is absorbed only by some plants (legumes). A deficiency of nitrogen in the soil inhibits plant growth and consequently leads to the reduction of agricultural yields. However, it may be supplemented by fertilization of soils. It is estimated that without the use of mineral fertilizers only 60% of the global population could be nourished [1]. The prospect of the predicted fast rate of global population increase in the coming decades requires the agricultural production to be more efficient and the demand for mineral fertilizers to increase at the same time. The large-scale fertilizer industry is based on ammonia synthesis whereby nitrogen from air is changed from an inactive N2 molecule to active NH3. A very high NN binding energy and a small value of the equilibrium constant of NH3 synthesis in the range of low pressures cause that this process requires the use of high temperatures and high pressure. A moderation of synthesis conditions can be achieved by the introduction of a catalyst. The iron catalyst is a contact commonly used in industrial ammonia synthesis [2–5]. It works effectively within a temperature range of 400–500°C and under the pressure of 15–30MPa. At the end of the twentieth century the second catalyst, with ruthenium as an active phase supported on activated carbon [6–15], was introduced to the industrial practice. Although the NH3 synthesis catalysts are known and have been studied from over 100 years, it is still an important and current issue, especially from the point of view of the industry. Despite the use of a catalyst, ammonia synthesis is a highly energy-consuming process. It is estimated that it consumes approx. 1% of the global energy produced each year [16]. An optimization of the process, however, is still possible, and one of the main directions is to develop a new, active catalyst working efficiently in NH3 synthesis plants under milder conditions of temperature and pressure. It would, in turn, significantly reduce the energy consumption of the process. Nowadays, catalyst systems with cobalt as the active phase [17–28] are the object of extensive studies. This metal exhibits a significant potential for catalysing NH3 synthesis. For this reason great hopes are placed on it to obtain a new, active catalyst, operating under milder conditions than the commonly used iron catalyst. Due to the relatively low activity of pure cobalt in ammonia synthesis [29], the introduction of properly selected additives became necessary. Previous studies have focused mainly on the promotion effects of alkali metals [30–32], alkaline earth metals [17–21], as well as rare earth metals (especially cerium) [22–28]. In our previous paper [27] it has been found that lanthanum has a positive promotion effect on the catalytic systems based on cobalt and co-promoted with barium. It has been stated that La may play a role of a structural promoter, which significantly improves the textural properties and prevents sintering. Nevertheless, the lanthanum content is not without significance in this type of catalysts. Therefore, the aim of this work was the development of active cobalt-lanthanum catalysts promoted with barium and a determination of the effect of lanthanum content on the physicochemical properties and activity of the tested catalysts in NH3 synthesis. The studies were focused on a detailed characterization of cobalt catalysts with various lanthanum content. This allowed us to identify the role of lanthanum in the obtained catalytic systems. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The detailed description of the preparation procedure can be found in our previous paper [27]. Briefly, Co/Ba catalyst sample was obtained by precipitation of cobalt carbonate and its subsequent calcination. In contrast, Co/La/Ba catalyst samples were obtained by co-precipitation of a mixture of cobalt carbonate and lanthanum carbonate and their subsequent calcination. Appropriate amounts of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (POCH) or a mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and La(NO3)3·6H2O (Alfa Aesar GmbH&Co) were dissolved in distilled water and heated to approx. 90°C. Then, a warm solution of K2CO3 (POCH) as a precipitant was added. The obtained precipitates were filtered, washed, dried at 120°C and subsequently calcined at 500°C in air. Then the prepared oxide materials were impregnated with an aqueous solution of the promoter salt (Ba(NO2)2 (Pfaltz & Bauer) using the incipient wetness technique. The final step of the preparation was crushing and sieving the solid materials (0.2–0.63mm fraction). The chemical composition of the resulting catalysts is presented in Table 1 . A reference material (Co3O4) was also prepared by precipitation and calcination (air, 500°C) of CoCO3. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The phase composition of the catalyst samples in oxidized forms, as well as that of the reduced materials (after catalytic tests), was characterized by X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD). Measurements were carried out at room temperature with a hybrid Rigaku-Denki Geigerflex diffractometer in a Bragg–Brentano configuration. The working condition was 40kV and 40mA. Diffraction data were collected in the scattering 2θ range of 15–100° with a 0.02° step. The textural parameters of catalyst precursors were measured by using a N2 physisorption with an ASAP 2020 instrument from Micromeritics. Before the measurement, each sample was degassed under vacuum at 90°C for 1h and then at 200°C for the next 4h. The reduction behaviour of the fresh catalysts was investigated by temperature-programmed reduction coupled with mass spectrometry. The TPR-MS experiments were conducted using a NETZSCH STA 449C thermobalance equipped with a quadrupole mass spectrometer NETZSCH QMS Äeolos 403C. Samples (approx. 15mg) were heated to 550°C (10°Cmin−1) in a 10%H2/Ar mixture (flow rate: 100mlmin−1). Then the temperature and gaseous atmosphere were maintained for 2h (isothermal segment). The mass change, temperature and selected m/e signals were monitored throughout the entire experiment. The morphology and homogeneity of the samples was determined with a Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope (FEI NovaNanoSEM 230) equipped with an EDX spectrometer (EDAX Genesis XM4). The surface area of metallic Co was evaluated by the H2 chemisorption measurements (TPD-H2) using a fully automated flow set-up PEAK4 after reduction of the samples at 550°C for 16h in a 80%H2/Ar (flow rate: 40mlmin−1). The details of such experiments can be found elsewhere [23,27]. The hydrogen desorbed was monitored with a thermal conductive detector (TCD). The obtained desorption profile allowed for the determination of H2 amount desorbed from the Co surface. The surface of the active phase was calculated based on H:CoS =1:1 stoichiometry [34] and the equation proposed by Borodziński and Bonarowska [35]. 2.3 Catalytic measurements Ammonia synthesis rates were measured in a flow tubular reactor supplied with a very pure (≥99.99995vol.%) H2/N2 =3:1 mixture of controlled NH3 content (0–8mol%) [36]. Prior to activity measurements, catalysts were reduced in the reacting gas mixture according to following procedure: at 470°C for 24h, then 520°C for next 24h and finally at 550°C for 48h. The activity was tested under steady-state conditions (370–430°C, 6.3MPa, gas flow rate: 70.0dm3 h−1). The concentration of NH3 in the outlet gas (x2) was monitored—integral measurement (x1 =0) and the productivity was determined. The details of the described experiments can be found elsewhere [36]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Properties of catalyst precursors The phase composition of all obtained cobalt-lanthanum catalyst precursors was studied using X-ray diffraction (XRPD). In the diffraction patterns of precursors with a low lanthanum content (up to 7.4wt.%) only one crystalline phase is present, namely cobalt oxide Co3O4 (Fig. 1 ). At higher La content (in the range of 19.3–55.7wt.%) the signals from lanthanum cobaltite (LaCoO3) are also seen, which results from an interaction of the main components of the catalyst precursor (Co and La) under the conditions of their preparation. The increase in the La content is accompanied by a decrease in an intensity of signals derived from cobalt oxide—the higher the La content in the tested sample, the weaker the Co3O4 signals, as can be clearly seen in the range of 35–38° and 63–68°. On the other hand, with increasing lanthanum content the progressive appearance and increase of the intensity of LaCoO3 phase signals can be observed (see Fig. 1—the range of diffraction angles 46–50°). No signals typical for La2O3 have been detected, whereas the signals of La2O2CO3 were identified. The presence of this phase may result from a transformation of La2O3 caused by its interaction with carbon dioxide contained in ambient air [37,38] or may be derived from the incomplete decomposition of lanthanum carbonate to lanthanum oxide [37,39,40]. The La2O2CO3 phase is a stable intermediate of this reaction. However, signals derived from La2O2CO3 phase were observed only in the materials with a high lanthanum content (29.3–55.7wt.%). Cobalt-lanthanum catalyst precursors, as well as Co3O4 (as a reference material) were subjected to physisorption studies consisting of a determination of the following textural parameters: a total specific surface area (SBET), a pore volume (VP) and a pore volume distribution. Complete N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were also obtained for all tested materials. The values of SBET and VP are summarized in Table 2 . The specific surface area of cobalt oxide (42.9m2/g) significantly increases due to the introduction of lanthanum to the sample. The addition of even a small amount of lanthanum (1.8wt.%) to Co3O4 (Co/La (1.8) sample) results in a substantial increase in the total surface area (SBET) of the material (approx. 67%). The highest specific surface area and pore volume exhibits a system with the addition of 7.4wt.% of lanthanum (Co/La(7.4)—86.5m2/g and 0.432cm3/g, respectively). For this precursor more than a twofold increase in the surface area in relation to pure Co3O4 was observed. This clearly indicates a structural role of lanthanum—it affects the development of the surface area of catalyst precursors and may prevent their sintering under calcination conditions. However, increasing lanthanum content to more than 19wt.% results in the decrease of the surface area of Co/La precursors. This effect is justified by an increasing contribution of the lanthanum precursor and the formation of lanthanum cobaltite (LaCoO3) in the tested cobalt-lanthanum systems. Cobalt-lanthanum catalyst precursors have a bimodal pore volume distribution, similar to that of pure cobalt oxide (Fig. 2 a). For all materials pores with an average width of approx. 40nm and 90nm are dominant. The shape of the obtained N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (Fig. 2b) was similar for all tested Co/La materials. It does not conform to any of the isotherm types defined by the IUPAC [41], which indicates that in the case of materials consisting of cobalt oxide and lanthanum oxide there are systems of mixed mesopores and macropores. 3.2 The characterization of catalysts in an active form In our previous paper [27] it has been shown that lanthanum has a negative effect on the reduction of cobalt oxide. In these studies attention is focused on the influence of the La content on the course of reduction of the studied cobalt-lanthanum catalysts. Temperature-programmed reduction measurements were carried out for pure cobalt oxide (Co3O4) and selected Co/La systems of low, medium or high lanthanum content. The experimental results are shown in Fig. 3 . The mass losses visible on the TG curves (Fig. 3a) are related to the evolution of water (Fig. 3b), which is the main product of the reduction of cobalt oxide with hydrogen. For pure Co3O4 a two-step reduction was observed. The two visible mass losses on the TG curve correspond to two distinct mass signals of water, with a maximum at temperature of 290°C (reduction of Co3+ →Co2+) and about 440°C (reduction of Co2+ →Co°). The reduction of cobalt oxide finished at the stage of temperature increase at about 500°C. The presence of lanthanum changes the course of the reduction of Co3O4 in Co/La samples, but this effect varies depending on the lanthanum content in the tested material. The reduction of Co3O4 in the sample with a low content of lanthanum (Co/La(1.8)) was complete at the stage of temperature increase at about 500°C, as in the case of pure Co3O4. However, a shift of a maximum of H2O mass signal peaks (Fig. 3b) towards lower temperatures (260°C and 360°C, respectively) was observed. The reduction of materials with a higher lanthanum content (7.4–55.7wt.%) took longer and ended during the isothermal step at 550°C. It is noteworthy that the higher the La content in the sample, the longer the reduction, as evidenced by the time that was required to stabilize the TG curves of samples with large amounts of lanthanum (Fig. 3a). Moreover, a shift of the maximum of H2O mass signals towards higher temperature than for pure Co3O4 was observed. In addition, a substantial complexity of the mass spectra (3 and 4 partially overlapped H2O signals were noticed for samples: Co/La (29.3), Co/La(38.8) and Co/La(55.7)). In these cases the complex course of the reduction may be associated with the presence of an additional cobalt-containing phase (LaCoO3), which was also reduced under the experiment conditions in accordance with the equation: 2LaCoO3 +3H2 =La2O3 +2Co+3H2O The above process gave an additional contribution to the observed H2O mass signal. All these observations confirm that the presence of lanthanum in the cobalt-lanthanum oxide systems has a negative impact on the process of their reduction. The introduction of medium and large amount of lanthanum, i.e. ≥7.4wt.%, significantly prolongs the time required to the complete reduction of the studied systems. The analysis of a phase composition of the catalysts in the reduced form (unloaded from the NH3 synthesis reactor after catalytic tests)—Fig. 4 showed that in all the studied catalysts a metallic Co phase is present as a result of the reduction of phases containing cobalt (Co3O4 and LaCoO3). Signals derived from La2O3 are already visible for the catalyst containing 7.4wt.% of La and with increasing lanthanum content in the sample an intensity of lanthanum oxide signals also increases (Fig. 4). This effect is caused by a reduction of LaCoO3, the content of which, as mentioned previously, increased with increasing amounts of lanthanum in a precursor sample (Fig. 1). In addition, sintering of La2O3, under both reduction, as well as NH3 synthesis conditions, is also possible. This results in the formation of larger, better ordered crystallites of lanthanum oxide. In the case of Co/La(4.6)/Ba and Co/La(55.7)/Ba catalysts the presence of La(OH)3 signals may be associated with the transformation of La2O3 on contact with air (ex-situ measurements). Signals derived from the barium promoter were observed only for catalysts with a low lanthanum content. The oxidation of barium oxide leads to the formation of BaO1.3 (JCPDS 47-1488), whose signals were visible for the Co/La(1.8)/Ba system. In contrast, for the Co/La(4.6)/Ba catalyst more intense signals of BaCO3 occurred. The presence of these two barium-containing phases results from changes of the barium precursor (barium nitrite) caused by an activation in the NH3 synthesis reactor and a subsequent contact with air (ex-situ XRPD measurements). The morphology and chemical composition of the surface layers of catalysts in the reduced form were determined using SEM-EDX studies (Fig. 5 ). The cobalt catalyst without lanthanum (Co/Ba) shows a high heterogeneity of the structure. The promoter (Ba) is present in the form of separate particles mixed with cobalt. EDX multipoint analysis (data not shown) revealed an uneven distribution of both components (Co and Ba). The catalyst with a low lanthanum content (Co/La(1.8)/Ba) exhibits a great similarity (in terms of heterogeneity and particle size) to the Co/Ba system. EDX analysis for this sample revealed an uneven distribution of cobalt and barium, visible in the EDX maps (Fig. 6 ). Significant differences in the morphology of the investigated catalysts appeared when La content in the catalysts is higher. For catalysts containing ≥19.3wt.% La a high homogeneity of the structure was observed (Fig. 5). Catalysts grains consist of fine particles. It seems that a medium and high lanthanum content in the catalyst prevents the growth of cobalt crystallites under NH3 synthesis conditions. EDX analysis (Fig. 6) for all tested systems containing lanthanum indicates that the higher lanthanum content in a catalyst, the more uniform distribution of Co and Ba on the catalyst surface. Moreover, a uniform distribution of lanthanum on the catalyst surface was observed regardless of La content in the sample. Therefore, structural studies confirm a hypothesis of the structure-forming properties of lanthanum in the investigated systems based on cobalt. The surface area of an active phase (metallic cobalt) was determined by temperature-programmed desorption studies. Hydrogen was used as a probe molecule and conditions of the experiments were chosen in such a way that H2 was chemisorbed only on the surface of cobalt. Our preliminary experiments have shown that under experimental conditions hydrogen is not adsorbed on the surface of lanthanum or barium compounds. Thus, the entire amount of gas chemisorbed during the experiment is related to the presence of metallic cobalt. Based on the amount of chemisorbed hydrogen and assuming a spherical model of the Co crystallites, the surface area of the active phase available for hydrogen was estimated (SH2 values—Fig. 7 ). After the reduction of catalysts at 550°C, the contact without lanthanum (Co/Ba) and with the lowest content of lanthanum (Co/La(1.8)/Ba) have the lowest surface of cobalt. Increasing the lanthanum content in the catalyst results in a gradual increase in the surface area of the active phase. Catalysts containing 4.6–7.4wt.% of lanthanum exhibit SH2 values about twice that of the system without lanthanum (Co/Ba) and SH2 significantly increases with increasing La content in the sample. Lanthanum-rich systems (38.8–55.7wt.%) possess a particularly high surface of an active phase (Fig. 7). Fig. 8 presents curves of hydrogen desorption from the surface of the selected catalysts. A TPD curve for the catalysts without lanthanum (Co/Ba) has only one broad peak with a maximum at 520°C. In contrast, two peaks were observed for all the catalysts containing lanthanum. The first peak with a maximum in the temperature range 103–140°C corresponds to desorption of H2 weakly bound to the surface of cobalt (low-temperature peak), whereas the second peak with a maximum at 520°C is associated with the desorption of H2 strongly interacting with the surface of the active phase (high-temperature peak). The presence of hydrogen strongly adsorbed on metal surface was previously observed for Ba-Ru-K/AC catalyst for NH3 synthesis [42]. The intensity of the signals, as well as the low-temperature/high-temperature peaks ratio (Fig. 8) visibly varies with the increase of the La content in the catalyst sample. A gradual increase in the low-temperature peak occurred, which was accompanied by the decrease of the high-temperature peak when the La content in the catalysts increased. In addition, a shift of the maximum of the low-temperature peak towards lower temperatures was observed. In summary, it can be stated that in the cobalt-lanthanum catalytic systems there are two types of sites on the cobalt surface on which hydrogen can be chemisorbed. The first are sites with a low activation energy (low-temperature sites), where H2 is bound weakly. And the second sites are those with a high activation energy (high-temperature sites), where H2 is bound strongly. The share of those sites on the cobalt surface depends on the amount of lanthanum in the material. This factor, in turn, affects the texture of the resulting catalyst. Therefore, it can be assumed that the low-temperature adsorption sites/high-temperature adsorption sites ratio is determined by the surface area of cobalt—the higher the cobalt surface, the higher the ratio. However, it cannot be excluded that this depends also on the presence of LaCoO3 in the catalyst precursor. The formation of this phase is undoubtedly dependent on the La content in the catalyst sample (XRPD studies − Fig. 1). 3.3 Catalytic activity in NH3 synthesis The results of the catalyst activity in NH3 synthesis are presented in Table 3 . After the catalyst activation, i.e. after reduction at 550°C, it was observed that with increasing lanthanum content the activity of the catalysts significantly increases. The system with a small amount of lanthanum (1.8wt.%) has an activity similar to the contact without lanthanum (Co/Ba). The increase of the La content to 7.4wt.% (Co/La(7.4)/Ba) causes a significant (by approx. 70%) increase in the activity. The catalyst with the highest lanthanum content (Co/La(55.7)/Ba) exhibits about 3.5-fold higher activity than the contact without the addition of lanthanum (Co/Ba). Comparing the productivity with the chemisorption data (Fig. 7) it can be clearly seen that the catalytic activity of the tested catalysts increases due to the increase of the surface area of the active phase (SH2). The following sequence of SH2 values was observed: Co/Ba<Co/La(7.4)/Ba<Co/La(29.3)/Ba<Co/La(55.7)/Ba, which translates directly for the activity of these catalysts in NH3 synthesis reaction. The apparent activation energy (E400-430), determined on the basis of the average reaction rate (productivity) was approx. 55kJ/mol for all the examined cobalt-lanthanum catalysts. This value is much lower than that for carbon-supported cobalt catalysts [17–20] or carbon-supported ruthenium catalysts [43,44], reported previously. It is noteworthy that it is also similar for the activation energy of the commercial iron catalyst KM1 [20]. Lin et al. [28] also found that the apparent energies of activation were approx. 50kJ/mol for ceria-supported cobalt catalysts for NH3 synthesis. In order to determine the thermal stability of the studied catalysts, the operation of a short-term overheating at a temperature higher (600°C) than the standard temperature of their reduction (550°C) was applied. This type of studies is commonly used in laboratories to determine the resistance to overheating of catalysts during their operation under high temperature conditions. It is assumed that if an activity does not decrease due to overheating at a temperature higher than the operating temperature, the catalyst is stable. Catalytic tests carried out after overheating show that the thermal stability of the cobalt-lanthanum catalysts depends on the lanthanum content in the sample (Table 3). For systems with a small addition of La (1.8–7.4wt.%) a decrease in the activity due to overheating at 600°C for 13h was approx. 30%. With increasing lanthanum content a thermal deactivation of the catalysts was insignificant—for contacts containing 19.3–29.3wt.% of La the activity decreased less than a few percent. The contacts with the highest La content (Co/La(38.8)/Ba and Co/La(55.7)/Ba) exhibit high resistance to overheating. After 13h of overheating at 600°C the activity of these systems slightly increased (by about 2.5% for Co/La(38.8)/Ba and about 10% for Co/La(55.7)/Ba). Subsequent overheating for the next 62h did not cause any change in their activity (data not presented). 3.4 The role of lanthanum in the studied catalysts Pure cobalt exhibits a very low activity in ammonia synthesis reaction [29]. In order to improve its catalytic properties the introduction of a promoter/promoters is required. Hence, the selection of appropriate additives is crucial for catalytic properties of these materials. In our preliminary studies [27] it has been found that lanthanum has a positive promotion effect on the catalytic systems based on cobalt. Further detailed chemisorption studies (Fig. 7) and activity measurements (Table 3), presented in this paper, showed a significant effect of the lanthanum content on catalytic properties of the investigated systems. The increasing lanthanum content in the catalyst is accompanied by a gradual increase of the surface area of the active phase and this relationship transferred directly to the activity of catalysts in NH3 synthesis. However, the analysis of TOF values (Table 3) shows that for the entire group of the studied catalysts TOF values are similar, regardless of the La content in the sample. This means that the activity of the catalysts surface is the same for all the obtained Co/La/Ba catalysts. Therefore, lanthanum does not work as an activator for the cobalt surface and the increase of the cobalt-lanthanum catalysts activity observed is only the result of the development of the active phase surface by lanthanum. It can be clearly seen that in the studied catalytic systems lanthanum acts as a typical structural promoter, which develops the active phase (cobalt) surface, but does not affect its activity in NH3 synthesis reaction. Structure-forming properties of lanthanum were already observed during textural measurements of precursors in the oxide form (Table 2, Fig. 2) and morphology of the reduced catalysts (Figs. 5 and 6). The addition of lanthanum to the cobalt system prevents the sintering of Co3O4 crystallites during calcination of Co/La precursors, as well as their subsequent reduction—the presence of the promoter in the reduced catalysts favored the homogeneity of the studied systems, particularly at high La content. As a consequence, the contacts in the reduced form consisted of small, well-dispersed particles, in which lanthanum was uniformly distributed on the surface. Thus, the promotion mechanism of lanthanum as a structural promoter is analogous to that of alumina in the fused iron catalyst [4,45]. The proposed role of lanthanum as a structural promoter in the cobalt-based systems corresponds well with the operation of another rare earth element—cerium, reported previously [22,23]. Similar structural properties of lanthanum were observed also for various catalysts of other processes [46,47]. The role of the second promoter – barium – may be more complex than the role of lanthanum. It can be clearly seen in Table 3 that TOF values for all catalysts co-promoted with lanthanum and barium (Co/La/Ba systems) are similar to that obtained for the system promoted only with barium (Co/Ba). In comparison, the catalyst promoted only with lanthanum (Co/La(7.4)), presented in our previous paper [27], has a 26 times lower TOF value (0.005s−1) than Co/Ba and Co/La/Ba systems. Hence, the activity of the cobalt surface in the Co/La(7.4) catalyst is very low and similar to that for pure cobalt (0.0004–0.0008s−1) [29]. It indicates that barium may be a promoter modifying the surface of cobalt. In addition, it may also act as a structural promoter—the introduction of Ba to the cobalt system significantly reduced sintering of metal crystallites [27]. Nevertheless, in the case of barium further extensive studies are required to precisely determine how barium interacts with the cobalt surface and changes its activity in NH3 synthesis. 5 Conclusions In the investigated catalytic systems lanthanum plays a role of an effective structural promoter. A close correlation between catalytic properties and the lanthanum content in the studied cobalt-based catalysts was observed. The increase of lanthanum content improves the textural parameters of catalyst precursors and causes the increase of the homogeneity of the catalysts in a reduced form. With increasing La content the surface area of the active phase (cobalt) is enlarged and thereby the activity of the catalysts increases. The thermal deactivation of catalysts was also less pronounced when La content increased. However, the introduction of medium and large amounts of lanthanum (≥7.4wt.%) significantly prolongs the time required to the complete reduction of the studied Co/La systems. coredata.dc:description: The effect of lanthanum content on catalytic properties of cobalt catalysts for ammonia synthesis has been studied. The amount of La in the studied catalysts ranged from 0 to 55.7wt.%, whereas the barium content was constant (approx. 1.5mmolgCo −1). The characterization studies included a determination of properties of the catalysts precursors (N2 physisorption, XRPD), as well as the catalysts in the active form (TPR-MS, XRPD, SEM-EDX and H2 chemisorption). The activity of the obtained Co/La/Ba catalysts in NH3 synthesis was tested in a flow differential reactor operating under conditions close to the industrial ones (p=6.3MPa, T=400°C, H2/N2 =3:1). It has been found that lanthanum plays the role of an effective structural promoter. However, there is a strong correlation between the La content in the catalysts and their properties: increasing amount of lanthanum is accompanied by the improvement in textural properties of both the precursors and catalysts in the reduced form. Lanthanum does not work as an activator for the cobalt surface. The increase in the activity of Co/La/Ba catalysts was observed as a result of a development of the active phase surface by increasing the La content.
coredata.dc:title: Promotion effect of lanthanum on the Co/La/Ba ammonia synthesis catalysts—the influence of lanthanum content
